Not yet sure what the issue is, but workaround for time being is likely to run your binary under environment variable setting: `GRPC_DNS_RESOLVER=native`, when using "Windows Server 2008 R2 64bit".

This has turned out to be a bit tricky to reproduce. Haven't yet been able to get C# DNS resolution on the 1.19 release to fail, even when using "Windows server 2008 R2".

@plaisted if you have time, mind running the binary under environment variable settings:

```
GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG
GRPC_TRACE=api,cares_resolver,cares_address_sorting
```

Also, can you share a bit more environment info, in particular are you running on a google cloud VM?

Regarding the workaround, we just reverted to 1.18 so fine there.

I'll try to recreate with the above traces enabled. The server runs in a private data center under hyper-V. It's a "legacy" environment from an acquisition so we've found some surprises before so could be an odd configuration of the server or similar contributing to the issue.

This is also impacting us on a variety of Windows 7/10 systems, setting `GRPC_DNS_RESOLVER=native` is a successful workaround but in the meantime we have rolled back to 1.18.0. The specific issue we are observing is with netbios names on ares resulting in Name Resolution Failure - IPs and 'normal' DNS are fine.
I'm surprised that there's environments that are fully relying on netbios without being backed up by a DNS system. Or are your netbios names not mapping with your DNS names correctly?

Perhaps - that could very well be a contributing factor, our software runs in a merchant datacenter and most of our clients configure it to use static IPs but some are doing unusual netbios configurations with legacy systems. 

We are able to reproduce on Windows using the local machine name - this resolves successfully with 1.18.0 and yields Name Resolution Failure with 1.19.0:

```
Environment.SetEnvironmentVariable("GRPC_VERBOSITY", "DEBUG");
Environment.SetEnvironmentVariable("GRPC_TRACE", "api,cares_resolver,cares_address_sorting");
var server = new Server
{
    Services =
    {
        Greeter.BindService(new GreeterImpl())
    },
    Ports = {new ServerPort(ServerHost, 10101, ServerCredentials.Insecure)}
};
server.Start();

//TODO: Put your local machine name here
var channel = new Channel("DESKTOP-1AB2CDE:10101", ChannelCredentials.Insecure);
var client = new Greeter.GreeterClient(channel);

await client.SayHello(new HelloRequest());
```

And produces the following debug trace (1809-17763.379, net472 and netcoreapp2.2):

Thanks for the log, that's an interesting error.

I would have expected c-ares lookups to fail somewhat quickly with an NXDOMAIN error, but what actually happened is that we failed to receive any response to the DNS queries at all. Eventually, gRPC's 10 second DNS resolution timer went off, and we cancelled the queries.

Looking at:

```
D0319 18:24:32.012821 0 T:\src\github\grpc\workspace_csharp_ext_windows_x64\src\core\ext\filters\client_channel\resolver\dns\c_ares\dns_resolver_ares.cc:433: (c-ares resolver) resolver:000001E7B9065370 Started resolving. pending_request_:000001E7B8FB0C70
D0319 18:24:42.025824 2094752319280 T:\src\github\grpc\workspace_csharp_ext_windows_x64\src\core\ext\filters\client_channel\resolver\dns\c_ares\grpc_ares_ev_driver.cc:212: (c-ares resolver) request:000001E7B8FB0C70 ev_driver=000001E7D357D9F0 on_timeout_locked. driver->shutting_down=0. err="No Error"
```

and `C-ares status is not ARES_SUCCESS: DNS query cancelled`

We updated the c-ares submodule dependency from the 1.13 c-ares release to the 1.15 release yesterday (in PR #18519). The latest c-ares release has, among other things, a fix for https://github.com/c-ares/c-ares/issues/150.

This is just a guess, but @plaisted @invidious9000 if you have the chance, it would be interesting if you could test with a C# build off the latest gRPC master branch commits (which have PR #18519). To do this, you would need to download one of the C# nugets from the [nightly package build page](https://packages.grpc.io/), from one of the recent builds, e.g. [this one](https://packages.grpc.io/archive/2019/03/59ffdd9929667d8d662d4bede6a21d4b3e35a93a-cfd9d051-5462-48ed-ae42-433593cf48ff/index.xml).
@plaisted @invidious9000 mind trying out the `1.20.0-pre1` release? This release has the updated c-ares dependency

Thanks for the log again. The error is noteably different, in that now this time there was in fact an NXDOMAIN, rather than timeout/dropped-query. Unfortunately it's still hard to say what the issue is.
